Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in biology and require a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science and engineering. The fellowships advance NSF efforts to diversify the STEM workforce now and in the future. This fellowship to Tim Mitchell supports research on the influence of the social environment on strategies for survival and reproduction in lizards. Training goals include techniques from ecology, evolution and genetics. The host institution is the University of Alabama at Birmingham, and the sponsoring scientist is Daniel Warner. The plans to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science are twofold: to develop a hands-on evolutionary ecology unit at a Birmingham City public high school that exposes students to scientific research and to communicate cutting-edge science and stories from a diverse range of high-quality scientists to 6-12 grade audiences through the creation of a website and collaboration with Youngzine, an online youth magazine.

The primary research objective is experimentally to evaluate the influence of population age structure on plasticity in life-history traits in wild island populations of brown anole lizards. Closely related focal hatchling lizards are being released onto replicate small islands with manipulated age structures. These populations either lack an adult population entirely or have a typical density of adult lizards. Accurate measurements of key life-history traits, which are predicted to vary in response to age structure, are being obtained with mark-recapture on molecular methods. This research tests fundamental predictions of life history theory and explores the role of life-history plasticity in the adaptation of a free-ranging vertebrate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals display remarkable variation in their life history: how quickly they reach sexual maturity, how frequently they reproduce, the size and number of offspring produced. This variation is produced by both genetic and environmental factors. Much of what we know about variation in life histories comes from observational studies in nature, or carefully controlled experiments in the laboratory. Yet large-scale field experiments, where environmental factors are manipulated in the field, have provided some of the largest advances in our understanding of life history evolution. Through this fellowship, I used both laboratory and field experiments to explore environmental and genetic factors influencing variation in reproduction in anole lizards.  Pairing carefully controlled laboratory studies of reproduction with field experiments that manipulated population densities on entire islands, I showed that lizards greatly alter their reproductive strategies throughout the year in ways that likely enhance offspring survival.  Baby lizards that hatch early in the season, when the overall population density is low, have much higher survival than those produced later in the season, when densities are high. Females maximize the number of offspring they produce early in the season to take advantage of these good conditions.  Later in the season, they produce fewer but larger offspring.  Larger offspring size is advantageous in the late season, when densities are high. Overall, this project has supported or partially supported 6 peer-reviewed publications to date, and the project is ongoing so more research papers are forthcoming.

           I have contributed to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences in three distinct ways. 1) During this fellowship I have personally mentored 9 undergraduate students (6 of which are from underrepresented groups) and 4 graduate students on research techniques, scientific writing, independent and collaborative scientific inquiry. These students have presented posters and talks at conferences, published papers, and many are continuing to pursue careers in science and science education. 2)Through a collaboration with the NSF-STEM IQ project at Auburn University, I also participated in a large-scale teacher training initiative for teachers in rural Alabama. This initiative increased participation of rural Alabama students in local, regional and national science fairs, trained teachers on how to properly incorporate science fairs into their curriculum, and helped to implement local and regional science fairs. 3) I developed and coordinated a section in a children’s magazine (Youngzine) that brought stories of a diversity of scientists and their research and careers to a worldwide readership of children. I recruited 12 early-career scientists to author 36 total articles geared towards children about science and science careers. Together these projects have helped to increase access and diversity in science, and provided authentic science experiences and training to many people.
